thread.title: Obama defends ‘Black Lives Matter’
thread.title_full: Obama defends ‘Black Lives Matter’ | The Seattle Times

author: GARDINER HARRIS
title: Obama defends ‘Black Lives Matter’
text:
WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that black Americans were not simply imagining concerns that they are often treated more harshly and less fairly by police officers than are whites.
“It’s real,” he said. “We have to take it seriously.”
And, during a panel discussion on criminal-justice reform here, he defended the Black Lives Matter movement, which has been criticized by some as being anti-white, and by police unions, in particular, as being anti-police.
“I think the reason the organizers used the phrase ‘black lives matter’ was not because they were suggesting that nobody else’s lives matter,” Obama said. “Rather, what they were suggesting was that there is a specific problem that is happening in the African-American community that is not happening in other communities. And that is a legitimate issue that we’ve got to address.”
 Early in his tenure, Obama was often reluctant to wade into racially charged issues. After the death of Michael Brown last year in Ferguson, Mo., Obama was widely seen as distant, leaving the passion and action to his attorney general at the time, Eric Holder Jr.
But as his presidency nears its end, Obama is shedding much of his reserve and has begun, often in starkly personal terms, to speak about race, drugs and crime. On Wednesday, speaking in West Virginia to people affected by drug abuse, he mentioned his own use of illegal drugs as a young man and promised “to be a little controversial.”
“But I’m in my last term, I only got a year left, and it’s not like my poll numbers are that high,” he said to laughter. “I figure I can go ahead and say it.”
Criminal-justice reform, with its sometimes racial overtones, has become one of the most important issues of Obama’s remaining months in office. In July, he addressed it in a speech at a meeting of the NAACP, and he became the first sitting president to visit a federal prison.
On Thursday, he spoke about the subject for nearly an hour. Next week, he will travel to Chicago to speak on the issue at the annual conclave of the International Association of Chiefs of Police. And Friday, the FBI director, James Comey, is scheduled to deliver the second of his widely anticipated addresses on race in police work.
In each of his speeches, Obama has been careful to emphasize the heroism and difficult work of most police officers, and he said Thursday that the Black Lives Matter movement was not anti-police.
“Everybody wants strong, effective law enforcement,” he said during a session moderated by Bill Keller, the editor-in-chief of The Marshall Project, a nonprofit criminal-justice news organization, and a former executive editor of The New York Times. “Everybody wants their kids to be safe when they’re walking to school.”
Obama is part of a growing and bipartisan consensus in Washington that something must be done to reduce the sentences of nonviolent offenders. The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 15-5 on Thursday to send to the full Senate legislation that would significantly reduce mandatory minimum sentences for nonviolent crimes, institute a new system for determining which offenders would be eligible for early release and create programs to better prepare them to return to their communities.
The bill was endorsed this week by representatives of Charles G. and David H. Koch, the conservative billionaires who are part of a broad coalition pushing an overhaul of sentencing laws.
A similar measure is taking shape in the House. Despite the momentum, it is unlikely that Congress will consider any final bill on criminal-justice initiatives before 2016.
The proposal is widely seen as a way of pushing back on decades’ worth of tough-on-crime efforts that filled prisons and jails with former drug addicts and others whose incarceration is hugely expensive and devastating to communities, and may do little to improve safety.
Asked whether he was worried that a spike in crime or some horrific attack would end the bipartisan consensus for reform, Obama said Thursday, “Those dangers are real.”
Because of such worries, Obama said the reform effort must be incremental and sustained. And it must be aided by improved collection of police and crime data on a national level, he said.
“The point is that the use of technology, the use of data combined with smart community policing, really can have an impact, can make a difference,” he said.
GARDINER HARRIS
